metadata.case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Trustees of M. Ct. M. Chidambaram Chettyar Memorial Trust

facts.text: United India Life Assurance Company Ltd. incorporated under Indian Companies Act, 1882, principal object life insurance business, registered as insurer under Life Insurance Act, VI of 1938.

July 15, 1955, extraordinary General Meeting of shareholders passed resolution sanctioning donation of Rs. 2 lakhs from Shareholders Dividend Account to proposed M. Ct. M. Chidambaram Chettyar Memorial Trust for promoting technical or business knowledge including insurance.
Appellants 2-4 were Directors of Company on date of resolution, appellant 4 Chairman.
December 6, 1955, five settlers including Company executed trust deed establishing charitable trust commemorating Late M. Ct. M. Chidambaram Chettyar, initial sum Rs. 25,000.

Trust objects: establish scholarships, chairs, competitions, promote art/science/industrial/technical/business knowledge including insurance/banking/commerce/industry, support charities improving human relations, educational institutions/libraries, donations to charitable institutions.
Appellants 2,3,4 nominated trustees under deed, first appellant appointed under cl.8.
In pursuance of July 15, 1955 resolution, Company paid initial Rs. 5,000 to trustees, balance Rs. 1,95,000 on December 15, 1955.
July 1, 1956, Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 brought into force.
September 1, 1956 notified as appointed day under LIC Act; all assets/liabilities of controlled business of insurers including Company transferred to/vested in Life Insurance Corporation.
September 30, 1957, Corporation called upon appellants to refund Rs. 2 lakhs received by trust from Company.
December 10, 1957, appellants denied liability to refund.

March 14, 1958, Corporation applied to Life Insurance Tribunal under LIC Act for order directing trustees to pay Rs. 2 lakhs with 6% interest from payment date; alleged resolution/payments ultra vires, not authorized by Memorandum, not in Company's interests.

Appellants' written statement: Directors authorized by Articles to make charitable donations; paid from Shareholders Dividend Account, exclusive property of shareholders held in trust; shareholders resolved to donate exercising ownership; not challengeable; trustees not personally liable.
December 20, 1958, Tribunal ordered appellants to pay jointly/severally Rs. 2 lakhs within 15 days, else 6% interest till realization.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.
Articles 116,117: Interest on paid-up capital 6% and 1/10th remaining surplus exclusive property of shareholders carried to Shareholders Dividend Account.
Article 119: Dividend/bonus from Shareholders Dividend Account.
Articles 123,124: No larger dividend than recommended by Directors; payable only from Shareholders Dividend Account.
At July 15, 1955 meeting, Directors recommended interim dividend Rs.50/share, resolved to pay; impugned resolution separate donation, no dividend declared.

legal_issues.text: Whether resolution dated July 15, 1955 donating Rs. 2 lakhs from Shareholders Dividend Account was ultra vires the Company.
Whether Shareholders Dividend Account constituted exclusive property of shareholders vesting absolute right of disposal prior to dividend declaration.
Whether appellants as trustees personally liable to refund the amount.
Whether payment to trust created valid contract supported by consideration.

petitioner_arguments.text: Directors authorised by Articles of Association to make donations to charitable/benevolent/public objects.

Rs. 2 lakhs paid from Shareholders Dividend Account, distinct from general assets, exclusive property of shareholders held in trust; shareholders had absolute disposal right; donation by shareholder resolution unchallengeable.
Even if Company not taken over, payment not challengeable as ultra vires; Corporation's powers not larger.
As trustees, not personally liable to refund.
Resolution and acceptance by trustees constituted contract.

respondent_arguments.text: Resolution dated July 15, 1955 and payments ultra vires and void; Memorandum did not authorise; not in interests of Company's business; not generally recognised method; no direct/substantial advantage to Company.

court_reasoning.text: Right of Corporation to demand refund if unauthorised upheld by s.15 LIC Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.15(1)(a) allows application for payments without consideration or imprudent within 5 years before Jan 19,1956; Tribunal to make just order.

court_reasoning.text: Shareholders Dividend Account created per Insurance Act s.49 restricting dividends from life insurance fund; amounts per Arts.116,117 exclusive to shareholders meaning policyholders have no interest, but no proprietary interest until dividend declared; fund belongs to Company until dividend resolution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Shareholders not creditors until declaration; cites Bacha F. Guzdar.

court_reasoning.text: July 15, 1955 resolution donation not dividend declaration; separate from interim dividend resolution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Every payment from Account not dividend; requires Directors' recommendation and Company resolution.

court_reasoning.text: No contract: no consideration from trustees; mere acceptance of donation gratuitous gift.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.2(d) Contract Act requires valuable consideration; willingness to use for trust insufficient.

court_reasoning.text: Memorandum objects: carry life insurance business, invest/deal funds per Articles; donation not incidental/conducive; no connection to insurance business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ultra vires acts void, unratifiable; Art.93(t) subordinate to MoA; cites Ashbury, Egyptian Salt.

court_reasoning.text: Trust objects include insurance knowledge promotion but no obligation; benefit too indirect.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not reasonably proximate; cites Tomkinson v. South Eastern Railway.

court_reasoning.text: Appellants 1,2,4 as Directors responsible for ultra vires resolution personally liable; trustees benefited without right.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.15(2) LIC Act empowers Tribunal order considering responsibility/benefit.

holdings.text: Resolution donating Rs. 2 lakhs ultra vires as beyond Memorandum objects.
Shareholders Dividend Account belongs to Company until dividend declared; no prior proprietary interest.
Appellant trustees/Directors personally liable to refund Rs. 2 lakhs.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bacha F. Guzdar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Shareholder entitled to participate in profits only if/when dividend declared; no interest in assets until winding up.

precedents_cited.case_name: Egyptian Salt & Soda Co. v. Port Said Salt Association
precedents_cited.relevance: Memorandum construed fairly per legal documents principles.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ashbury Railway Carriages & Iron Co. v. Riche
precedents_cited.relevance: Company cannot pursue objects beyond Memorandum; ultra vires acts void.

precedents_cited.case_name: Re Birkbeck Permanent Benefit Building Society
precedents_cited.relevance: Ultra vires acts absolutely void, unratifiable even by all shareholders.
Railway company donation to Imperial Institute ultra vires despite indirect traffic benefit.
Memorandum read with Articles where ambiguous/silent, but Articles cannot extend scope.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer of controlled business; relief for unauthorised payments without consideration/imprudent; Tribunal orders.

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Act, 1938
statutes_cited.relevance: Restrictions on dividends from life fund; separate life fund security for policyholders; actuarial valuations.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Consideration required for contract; mere acceptance of donation not valuable consideration.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Tribunal order upheld directing appellants to pay Rs. 2 lakhs jointly/severally with 6% interest if default.
outcome.relief_granted: Refund of Rs. 2 lakhs to Corporation with interest.

key_quotes.text: The fund, therefore, belongs to the Company, and continues to so belong until its destination is determined by a resolution of the Company declaring a dividend pursuant to a recommendation of the Directors.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies ownership of Shareholders Dividend Account.

key_quotes.text: A Company is competent to carry out its objects specified in the Memorandum of Association and cannot travel beyond the objects.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Where a Company does an act which is ultra vires, no legal relationship or effect ensues therefrom. Such an act is absolutely void and cannot be ratified even if all the shareholders agree.
key_quotes.speaker: court
